Prisoner is one of Napa’s popular wines. It also glamorizes something ugly

There is no winery in Napa Valley like the Prisoner Wine Co. The sleek building with dangling shackles decor is a popular attraction. Its wine, the Prisoner red blend, is among the nation’s best-selling — a wine for the people, even at its high price point. But few have questioned a fundamental aspect of the brand: its use of imprisonment as a marketing aesthetic.
Dairy cows’ greenhouse gas emissions cut by 52% after eating seaweed
